Project Number: 53124-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
February 2020 
 
 
Understanding Disaster Displacement in Asia and the 
Pacific 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB's Access to Information 
Policy.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will help developing member 
countries (DMCs) prepare for and respond to disasters by enhancing their understanding of 
disaster displacement.1 To do so, the TA will (i) generate knowledge on disaster displacement, 
focusing on characteristics, trends, and cost; and (ii) support selected DMCs to make evidence-
based decisions on preparing for, responding to, and managing displacement risks. A greater 
understanding of the dynamics of disaster displacement can reduce the socioeconomic impacts 
and long-term consequences disasters can have on development, particularly for the most 
vulnerable. 
 
2.  The TA is consistent with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) Strategy 2030’s operational 
priorities  on  tackling  climate  change,  building  climate  and  disaster  resilience,  enhancing 
environmental sustainability, and strengthening governance and institutional capacity.2 Under 
Strategy 2030, ADB will ensure a comprehensive approach to building disaster resilience. The 
TA is included in the 2019 and 2020 management-approved results-based work plan of the 
Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Natural hazards are inevitable. Although disaster risk reduction provides the most effective 
approach to preventing new disaster risks and reducing existing ones, residual risk remains. The 
increasing  frequency  and  intensity  of  natural  hazards  across  Asia  and  the  Pacific  require 
governments and communities to have an evidence-based understanding of the disaster risk 
faced and its potential implications. 
 
4.  Almost 75% of the world’s disaster displacement in 2018 occurred in Asia and the Pacific. 
A recent modeling published in 2018 estimated that 240 of every 100,000 people across the 
region  might  be  displaced  during  any  given  year  in  the  future,  not  including  preemptive 
evacuations. Floods will likely displace an estimated average of 11.5 million people each year in 
the region, 87% of whom will be in urban areas.4 
 
5.  Since the 1970s, ADB’s DMCs have considerably reduced the mortality associated with 
disasters, primarily because of improved early warning systems. Nevertheless, a person in Asia 
and the Pacific is still five times more likely to be affected by a disaster than someone living in 
other regions.5 While mortality is decreasing, the number of people adversely affected—including 
by displacement—and the cost of disasters are rising.6 This increasing trend, largely driven by 
the  growing  concentration  of  people  and  assets  in  hazard-exposed  locations  and  an 
                                                
1  Disaster displacement is defined by the Platform on Disaster Displacement as “situations where people are forced 
to leave their homes or places of habitual residence as a result of a disaster or in order to avoid the impact of an 
immediate and foreseeable natural hazard. Such displacement results from the fact that affected persons are (i) 
exposed to (ii) a natural hazard in a situation where (iii) they are too vulnerable and lack the resilience to withstand 
the impacts of that hazard.” Platform on Disaster Displacement. Key Definitions. 
2  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. 
3  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 14 November 2019. 
4  Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre. 2018. Global Report on Internal Displacement. Geneva. 
5  United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific. 2017. Leave No One Behind: Disaster 
Resilience for Sustainable Development—Asia-Pacific Disaster Report 2017. Bangkok. 
6  United Nations Office for Disaster Risk Reduction. 2019. Global Assessment Report on Disaster Risk Reduction. 
Geneva.

2 
underinvestment in disaster risk reduction, underscores the need for greater investments in 
evidence-based disaster preparedness. 
 
6.  The numbers of people displaced or at risk of displacement are generally known at a 
national level, but gaps remain in understanding the multidimensional impacts of displacement, 
particularly the gender, socioeconomic, and temporal (temporary, including seasonal, or longer-
term) dimensions; the current and expected long-term trends of displacement risk; the key triggers 
and drivers, including climate change, policy approaches, and practices to managing such 
displacement; and the financial costs. Displacement impacts development. It affects human and 
social capital, economic growth, poverty reduction, and environmental sustainability gains; it 
increases fragility; and it disrupts lives. It can worsen vulnerabilities and create risks. During the 
response and recovery phases, certain groups—such as women, children, older people, people 
with  disabilities,  and  indigenous  communities—can  face  additional  challenges  that  further 
marginalize them. 
 
7.  Lack of understanding of the causes, scale, duration, and costs of displacement—as well 
as  trends—impedes  from  designing  and  implementing  appropriate  disaster  risk  reduction 
measures, including preparedness and response. Current research shows that sudden-onset 
natural hazard events (such as flash floods or storms) tend to drive short-term displacement and 
slow-onset events (such as droughts) drive more permanent and longer-range migration; in 
addition, evidence shows that abrupt, short-range population movement—and the demographic 
changes that implies—can indirectly influence longer-range migration.7 Many DMCs face multiple 
displacement triggers and need to enhance understanding to address displacement proactively 
with improved linkages to spatial development, early warning, social protection, and risk transfer 
measures. To address this, preparedness and development planning must account for both 
disaster and displacement risks, particularly because of projected urban growth and the likelihood 
that much of this growth will take place in informal settlements, where disaster and displacement 
risks are concentrated. 
 
8.  To enhance responses to disaster displacement, the international community agreed on 
a series of targets and directions in global agendas. The Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk 
Reduction, 2015–2030 calls for international and regional organizations to support efforts to build 
resilience and reduce displacement risk (priority 2), and for states to ensure rapid and effective 
response to disasters and related displacement (priority 3).8 The 2015 Paris Agreement on 
climate change established a task force on displacement to provide policy recommendations on 
integrated approaches to avert, minimize, and address displacement related to the adverse 
effects of climate change.9 A group of seven multilateral development banks, including ADB, 
established a platform to enhance and promote collaboration on economic migration and forced 
displacement to advance strategic dialogue and operational coordination and to maximize the 
impact of their growing engagement in these two areas. In addition, the 2030 Agenda for 
Sustainable Development (Sustainable Development Goal 10) and the global compacts on 
migration and refugees all recognize the need for coordinated, cross-sector actions to address 
diverse and region-specific human mobility challenges in the context of disaster displacement.10 
To realize these commitments, countries need further knowledge and analysis to enable informed 
and actionable policies and responses. 
                                                
7  ADB. 2017. A Region at Risk: The Human Dimensions of Climate Change in Asia and the Pacific. Manila. 
8  United Nations Office for Disaster Risk Reduction. 2015. Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction, 2015–
2030. Geneva. 
9  United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change. The Paris Agreement. 
10 Sustainable  Development  Knowledge  Platform.  Transforming  Our World:  The 2030  Agenda  for  Sustainable 
Development.

3 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: disaster resilience strengthened (footnote 8). 
The TA will have the following outcome: preparedness for disaster displacement enhanced.11 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
10.  Output 1: Knowledge of disaster displacement in Asia and the Pacific increased. 
Building on global analytical work, the TA will undertake research on disaster displacement in 
Asia and the Pacific, including an overview of trends and projections; an assessment of the 
temporal (temporary, including seasonal, or longer-term) nature of displacement; modeling and 
quantifying the cost of disaster displacement risk; and related gender displacement analysis. The 
TA  will  identify  potential  policy  measures  and  best  practice  to  support  preparedness  and 
management of displacement. 
 
11.  The research will downscale a global model on displacement to cover Asia and the 
Pacific.12 This includes (i) supporting the production of time-series data and disaggregation by 
gender, age, disability, and other characteristics; and (ii) using extrapolation and correlation 
analysis when required. The TA will conduct an economic impact assessment using disaster 
displacement data since 2008 and other relevant social and economic indicators to assess the 
risk of disaster displacement and calibrate the model with historical data. The TA will publish and 
widely disseminate the research digitally and make about 300 printed copies available at the high-
level launch of the report. 
 
12.  Output 2: Decision-making in developing member countries at high risk of disaster 
displacement improved. The TA will develop detailed disaster displacement profiles for up to 
four DMCs with some of the highest numbers and/or risk of disaster displacement to improve 
evidence-based decision-making, focusing on preparedness and managing displacement risks. 
In close consultation with ADB’s operational departments and prospective DMCs, the TA will 
select DMCs within the first quarter of implementation, based on criteria to identify suitability, 
including the level of displacement risk and enabling environment factors. 
 
13.  The TA will develop the profiles in consultation with participating DMCs, drawing on 
national data sets and accounting for country-specific drivers and downscaled global models on 
displacement risk. The profiles will (i) further elaborate disaster displacement risks at the country 
level by collecting, triangulating, and validating national data on displacement; and (ii) provide up-
to-date contextual analysis. This will include a review of domestic policies and traditional practices 
and an economic analysis of the cost of displacement to the DMC’s economy. The profiles will 
provide the basis for national roundtable discussions on possible policy measures to address 
displacement costs, outlining further areas for research and/or programmatic responses. The TA 
will make about 200 printed copies per DMC available to stakeholders. 
 
                                                
11 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
12 The Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre (IDMC) applies a two-step approach based on data gathering and 
modeling to estimate the number of people displaced by disasters. The methodology is a first step toward estimating 
a global stock figure for disaster displacement and can be enhanced with additional and more representative data, 
testing and validating it against observational data and employing more complex modeling methods.

4 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $600,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The key expenditure items are listed 
in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  ADB  will  administer  the  TA.  The  Sustainable  Development  and  Climate  Change 
Department will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants, including resource persons; organize 
workshops; and provide staff to act as resource persons in workshops. 
 
16.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table. 
 
Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects  Arrangements 
Indicative implementation period  January 2020–December 2022 
Executing agency  ADB 
Implementing agency  SDCC 
Consultants  To be selected and engaged by ADB 
Firm: IDMC  Single-source selection  $332,640 
Procurement  Procurement for workshops, training, seminars, and conferences will 
follow ADB’s Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) 
Disbursement  TA resources will be disbursed following ADB's Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
ADB = Asian Development Bank, IDMC = Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre, SDCC = Sustainable Development 
and Climate Change Department, TA = technical assistance. 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
17.  Consulting services. ADB will engage consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy 
(2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or 
staff instructions.13 ADB will engage the Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre (IDMC), which 
is part of the Norwegian Refugee Council, through single-source selection. IDMC was established 
in 1998 to provide high-quality data, analysis, and expertise on internal displacement to inform 
policy and operational decisions that can reduce the risk of displacement and improve the lives 
of internally displaced people worldwide. Considered a global authoritative source of data and 
analysis on internal displacement, IDMC offers rigorous, independent, and trusted services to the 
international community through its products and tools, including an annual global report on 
internal displacement, a probabilistic model on disaster displacement risk metrics, thematic and 
country research, and satellite imagery analysis.14 
 
18.  By engaging IDMC, ADB will harness the benefits of IDMC’s proprietary displacement 
models, analysis, and data sets, as well as its recognized expertise and thought leadership in the 
field.  IDMC’s  experience  and  sustained  engagement  in  displacement  since  1998,  and  the 
resulting data sets and original research, offer an accessible and unique source of intellectual 
property. Its engagement represents a natural continuation of its global modeling and research 
(footnote 4), and its downstream regional and national application offers a clear advantage over 
other research institutes engaged in displacement and/or human mobility. 
                                                
13 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3). 
14 Output-based and/or lump-sum contracts will be considered for consulting services where appropriate, with the 
concurrence of the Procurement, Portfolio and Financial Management Department.

5 
 
19.  ADB’s procurement. Procurement will follow the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as 
amended from time to time) and associated staff instructions and/or project administration 
instructions. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis for 
Understanding Disaster Displacement in Asia and the Pacific, and hereby reports this action to 
the Board.
